description: A prototype, gas-operated, assault rifle.  Bulky and brick-shaped, it was designed to be more accurate than any weapon in use, requiring a complete redesign from (almost) the ground up.  It features the bullpup design to reduce its overall size, a floating barrel, a rotary breech, and most importantly, the use of caseless ammo.  This combination enables high precision and reliability.  Despite the breakthrough, failure to improve over the accuracy requirement of the M16A2 standard, and issues inherent to the ammo prevented its final adoption.  One of the rarest weapons ever made.
//: I'm not sure if the caseless ammo issues were gone during either the K1 or K2 prototypes
//2: Should have its own integrated scope but I can't find the specs for it
//3: Assuming '100% more accurate than the G3' = 50% its dispersion. Which btw *is* more accurate than the M16 ingame

description: A prototype that never saw light of day, the '90s IDW is (would've been) the smallest SMG in the world.  Made from machined steel, the weapon is heavier than it looks.  Using 9mm Parabellum bullets, it was supposed to be highly customizable, allowing attachments for the stock, sights, barrels, and even a bipod.  It also featured an electronic control mechanism to regulate the rate of fire to automatically limit the recoil.

description: A semi-automatic .30-06 battle rifle, developed to compete after the M1 Garand entered production.  While it presented some advantages over its competitor, such as increased ammo capacity and the use of recoil to cycle, it's several minor disadvantages were enough to make the switch.

description: A famous bolt-action, internal magazine rifle.  Derived from the Standardmodell and Gewehr 98, the Kar98 inherited the well stablished, yet even more optimized Mauser action on a carbine design, fully Versailles '19 compliant.

description: A gas-operated, rotating bolt semi-automatic rifle.  Developed in 1904 and finished in 1908, the rifle features a (then) unusual mechanism, capable of self-loading while shooting.  It was serviced during the Mexican Revolution, and later by the German front in WWI, as it was considered an improvement over the Gewehr 98 and 9mm pistols.  Its last presence was in Switzerland, where it was modified to fit 7mm Mauser-derived ammo.

description: A gas-operated, semi-automatic Serbian DMR, based on the Soviet SVD-63.  Created to fulfill the (then novel) role as its spiritual predecesor, it was first deployed during the Yugoslav Wars.  Unlike the SVD however, the M76 is actually based on the AK design, overhauled to fit the bigger 7.92x57mm Mauser.
//: Accuracy is typically around 1.5 MOA, which is good for a Kalashnikov design and entirely acceptable for the designated marksman role.

description: Also known as SG 550, this weapon is a selective fire automatic rifle designed for the Swiss military.  This is an old iteration of the 550 series, heavier and bulkier.
//2: I don't understand where these dispersion values come from. For reference, M16 has 10 shot group dispersion of 32 cm @ 300 m (calculated ~3.84 moa), AK-47 has 10 shot dispersion of 44 cm @ 300 m (calculated ~5.28 moa)), AK-74 has a R50 of 24 cm @ 300 m ( 24*2*0.937 ≈ 45 cm = 5.4 moa). But, both M16 and AK-74 have 150 dispersion in C:DDA. To make things worse (for me), SIG 550 has a R50 of 14 cm @ 300 m ( 14*2*0.937 ≈ 26.2 cm = 3.14 moa), which is LOWER than M16 but dispersion for the SIG 553 is 180 in C:DDA. M4A1 has a 24 in grouping at 300 yards = 8 moa, but 180 dispersion in C:DDA too

description: The SKT-40 is a gas-operated, Soviet semi-automatic battle rifle.  It was originally intended to be replace the Mosin–Nagant rifle, before the events of WWII.  While still deployed on the battlefield, its numbers never got close to either its predecessor or successor, making it quite overpriced, relatively speaking.  This is the modernized, carbine version of the SVT-40, using 7.62x39mm.

The SVT-38 is a gas-operated, Soviet semi-automatic battle rifle.  It was originally intended to be replace the Mosin–Nagant rifle, before the events of WWII.  Although it was deployed in combat, issues such as its low durability and effective range caused the development and production of the SVT-40.

description: A retrofuturistic-looking, gas-operated, bullpup assault rifle, featuring a bakelite case.  Created in the early '60s and featuring a bakelite case, the weapon was intended to serve as a smaller, portable replacement to the AKM.  Some issues, like the shifted center of gravity, the bakelite's durability, and the radical appearance, were enough for its rejection.

description: The VSK-94 is a compact, gas-operated, subsonic DMR featuring an integrated supressor.  Belongs to the "spetsialnaya" group, which includes weapons such as the SR-3MP and the VSS.  The VSK-94 can be considered the sniper variant of the 9A-91, featuring a few components made with polymer.  Uses 9x39mm ammo.

The VSS is a compact, subsonic Soviet DMR featuring an integrated supressor and PSO-1 scope.  Designed alongside other "spetsialnaya" group Soviet era weapons such as the AS Val and the OTs-14 "Groza", in order to replace general use weapons, such as the AK-74.  Ironically enough, the Vintorez also lacks a niche: it can be used in stealth operations, as marksman rifle, as a pseudo-SMG, and as general use "assault weapon".  The only downsides are the relative low effective range and the pronunciated bullet drop, both due the properties of the 9x39mm.
